title: Recollections of a Long Life; An Autobiography
author: Cuyler, Theodore L. (Theodore Ledyard)
snippet: Let me add that I havepublished a single volume of sermons, entitled "The Eagle's Nest," and avolume of foreign travel, "From the Nile to Norway"; but all theremainder of my score of volumes have been of a practical and devotionalcharacter.

title: Recollections of a Long Life; An Autobiography
author: Cuyler, Theodore L. (Theodore Ledyard)
snippet: Let me add that I havepublished a single volume of sermons, entitled "The Eagle's Nest," and avolume of foreign travel, "From the Nile to Norway"; but all theremainder of my score of volumes have been of a practical and devotionalcharacter.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Wild yet gentle was the blue aerial haze over the glimpses of the Upper Lake, where soft and sweet, in a girdle of rocks, seemed to be hanging, now in air and now in water — for all was strangely indistinct in the dim confusion — masses of green light that might be islands with their lovely trees ; but suddenly tipt with fire shone out the golden pinnacles  of the Eagle's Nest ; and as again they were tamed by cloud-shadow, the glow of Purple Mountain for a while enchained  our vision, and then left it free to feast on the forests of Grlena, till, wandering at the capricious will of fancy, it floated in delight over the woods of Mucruss, and long lost among the trembling imagery of the water, found lasting repose on the steadfast beauty of the sylvan isle of Inisfallen.

title: Noctes Ambrosianæ.
author: Wilson, John
snippet: In an Eagle's Nest.

title: The recreations of Christopher North

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :

title: The British isles,
author: Tomlinson, Everett T.
snippet: The swift, clear waters, the green foliage on the banks, the Eagle's Nest, — a hill having steep sides that rise seventeen  hundred feet from the shore, — the heavy, floating clouds on the hillside, the silence that rests over the place, make the spot one of rare beauty.

title: The British isles through an opera glass,
author: Taylor, Charles M.
snippet: We are under the shadow of Eagle's Nest, noted for its beautiful echo.

title: The British isles through an opera glass,
author: Taylor, Charles M.
snippet: mountain opposite is Eagle's Nest.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: In an almost inaccessible place near what is called theEagle's Nest, lived a Princess of Bantry of the olden time,whose Prince had been defeated and driven away by theEnglish, the flocks and herds and growing crops destroyed,or carried away as spoil, so that the faithful servitor, towhose care were confided the poor homeless Princess andher children, knew not how to support them.

title: We four.
author: Rees, L. L.
snippet: The Lakes of Killarney, the Upper Lake, Lake Muckross, and Lough Leane are beautifully surrounded by mountain ranges, among which are Mount Tore and the Eagle's Nest, the latter rising twelve hundred feet above the water's edge.

title: We four.
author: Rees, L. L.
snippet: Here one commands a fine view of Mangerton, Tore, Eagle's Nest, Purple  Mountains, Grienna, Tomies, and Carrantual.

title: Shamrock and thistle;
author: Optic, Oliver
snippet: The Eagle's Nest was a rugged and precipitous mass of rock, rising seven hundred feet above the river, full of crevices, in which the eagle builds his nest.

title: Shamrock and thistle;
author: Optic, Oliver
snippet: Now he called their attention to the Eagle's Nest, a high cliff", at the top of which lived the majestic bird ; and then he pointed down into the lake, where some saint had imprisoned some demon.

title: Sights and sensations in Europe :
author: Browne, Junius Henri
snippet: At the entrance is Coleman's Eye, a singular and picturesque promontory, and further on a pei-pendicular cliff called the Eagle's Nest, so remarkable for its echoes that some of the gufdes declare that when you cry out " How do you do ?" the echo responds, " Yery well, I thank you, and won't you take a drop of whiskey?"

author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
